title: Ohio Proposal Would Award Electoral Votes to Popular Vote Winner
content: The scenario you describe is accurate. However, I don't agree that it is comparable to the "'Hanging Chad' fiasco." The latter was a matter of how to deal with vote counts at the precinct level and when to declare recounts are no longer valid. The former is a matter of how a state distributes its electoral votes. The matter will surely be argued before the SCOTUS eventually, but it is not about a particular election; rather it is about interpreting Article II of the Constitution.

content:
Okay...so I'm obviously not contesting the mechanical of how the Electoral College works. That's obviously how the President is elected.
But it is true that the Electoral College only "protects" some voters by weighting their votes over others. I'm sure you've noticed that Presidential candidates really only campaign in a handful of states. And you can ask California conservatives and Tennessee Democrats how much their voice matters in the general election. That's why I said the EC makes swaths of American votes effectively meaningless.

title: Actress Michelle Williams Rallies Support For Equal Pay Day in DC
content:
It's very simple, ladies: do equal work, get equal pay. Does anyone really think businesses wouldn't hire only women if they could cut down on labor costs?
It's been proven, time and time again, women don't want to work the same hours men do, or go into the same professions men do. No whining about it at a rally is going to change women into men.
I was amused recently when Google did a pay study on their employees, to try to adjust wages to be more fair between men and women, and ended up having to increase the pay of a lot more men than women.
When you account for the hours, the type of work, and levels of experience, men always put in more time in more valuable jobs for society. We don't need more baristas with gender studies degrees. We need more scientists, inventors, and engineers, and we need them to stick around in the workplace, for long careers. Most women only play at work. They go into a job for a few years, until they find a husband and quit, or quit when they get pregnant. A male employee is a much better investment, and while it's generally illegal to discriminate knowing full well a female employee is likely to be leaving the company in a few short years, it's absurd to compare the salaries of a woman who just started with a man who's been on a 30 year career track.
Seeing as how study after study has shown that women who work instead of having families are generally far less happy with their lives, and those women who do work tend not to work for very long, I think it's absolutely scandalous that women now account for most of the university degrees earned each year. We are frankly wasting resources on short-term employees. Dorm rooms are now filled with young women who will not get degrees that are very important to society, and will ultimately accumulate massive debts they'll never be able to pay off themselves. Men filling those dorm rooms are statistically far more likely to go into important jobs that benefit everyone, stay in those careers for decades, and ultimately contribute far far more to university endowments. This is certainly not politically correct to say, but I think at this point we should be very seriously questioning the wisdom of sending women to college at all, or having women in the workforce at all. Women would be happier not to bother, and men's salaries would likely increase without temporary competition from women. More men would be able to get degrees that add in a big way to the nation's economy, and universities would have more money from financial contributions of graduates, which they could reinvest in improving our educational institutions and doing more cutting-edge research.
